page.title: 04FLORA ON THE OLD MOUND
page.content: The old mound lies to the north of the School and was the site of an ancient settlement. There is a wide variety of wild plants due to the lack of disturbance by agriculture. These include flowers such as Tormentil, Tufted Vetch, Cowslips, Bluebells, Daffodils and Germander Speedwell. Other ground flora include Meadow, Timothy, Cocksfoot, Couch, and Rye Grass as well as Meadow Foxtail and Spring Sedge. There are also a number of different trees including two Silver Birch, a very young Oak and a mature Plane. There are a number of fallen and cut logs which provide a suitable habitat for toadstools such as Psalliota Semota. These have grown to 5-10 cms.This survey was carried out by Justin Whitthread in form 1H.
